docs.text:
See for yourself how starting age changes your final retirement balance. Adjust the starting age, annual contribution, and expected return to compare outcomes.

Try setting one scenario to age 22 and another to age 32. Watch the gap between the two lines widen as the years pass. That widening gap is compound growth in action, and it is why every year you wait costs you real money.

docs.title: Step-by-Step: Opening a Roth IRA at Fidelity
docs.text:
Fidelity Investments is one of the two most recommended brokerages for opening a Roth IRA. It charges no account fees, no minimums to open, and offers excellent low-cost index funds. Here is exactly what to do.

What you will need before you start:

  • Your Social Security number
  • Your bank account and routing number (for linking your checking account)
  • Your employer's name and address
  • A valid government ID
  • About 15 minutes

Step 1: Go to fidelity.com and click "Open an Account."

Step 2: Select "Roth IRA" from the account type options. Do not select "Traditional IRA" or "Brokerage Account." You want the Roth IRA specifically.

Step 3: Fill in your personal information: name, date of birth, Social Security number, address, and employment details. This is standard -- every brokerage is required to collect this by law.

Step 4: Link your bank account. Enter your checking account's routing number and account number. This is how you will transfer money into your Roth IRA.

Step 5: Set up your initial contribution. You can start with as little as $1. Fidelity has no minimum investment requirement. If you can, set up automatic monthly contributions. Even \(100/month (\)1,200/year) gets you started.

Step 6: Choose your investments. This is where most people get stuck, so do not overthink it. If you want the simplest option, pick a Fidelity Freedom Index Fund (a target-date fund based on your expected retirement year). If you are 25, pick the 2065 fund. If you are 22, pick the 2065 or 2070 fund. Done. We will cover more investment options later in this chapter.

Step 7: Confirm and submit. Your account is open. The first transfer from your bank usually takes 1-3 business days.

Fidelity's Best Feature for Beginners

Fidelity offers fractional shares, meaning you can buy a piece of an expensive stock or fund for as little as $1. You do not need thousands of dollars to start investing. They also have zero-expense-ratio index funds (FZROX for US stocks, FZILX for international), meaning you pay literally nothing in fund fees.

docs.title: Step-by-Step: Opening a Roth IRA at Vanguard
docs.text:
Vanguard is the other top recommendation. Vanguard is famous for pioneering low-cost index fund investing. It is owned by its fund shareholders (meaning you), so it has no outside owners trying to maximize profits at your expense.

What you will need before you start:

  • Your Social Security number
  • Your bank account and routing number
  • Your employer's name and address
  • A valid government ID
  • About 15 minutes

Step 1: Go to vanguard.com and click "Open an Account."

Step 2: Select "Roth IRA" as your account type.

Step 3: Enter your personal information, just like the Fidelity process: name, date of birth, Social Security number, address, and employment.

Step 4: Link your bank account by entering your routing and account numbers.

Step 5: Make your initial contribution. Vanguard's target-date funds have a $1,000 minimum investment. If you do not have $1,000 right away, you can invest in Vanguard ETFs (exchange-traded funds, which are like index funds that trade like stocks) with no minimum. A great starter option is VTI (Vanguard Total Stock Market ETF).

Step 6: Choose your investments. For simplicity, pick a Vanguard Target Retirement Fund matching your expected retirement year. If you are 25 years old, pick the Vanguard Target Retirement 2065 Fund (VLXVX). This single fund gives you a diversified mix of US stocks, international stocks, and bonds that automatically adjusts as you age.

Step 7: Set up automatic investments. Vanguard lets you schedule automatic transfers from your bank account on a recurring basis. Set it and forget it.

Step 8: Confirm everything and submit. Welcome to your Roth IRA.

Fidelity vs Vanguard: Which Should You Pick?

Both are excellent choices. You will not go wrong with either one. Fidelity has a slight edge for beginners because it has no minimums and a more modern website. Vanguard has a slight edge in philosophy (it is literally owned by its investors). Pick whichever feels more comfortable and open the account today. Do not let this decision become a reason to delay.

docs.title: What to Invest In: Investment Selection Inside Your IRA
docs.text:
Opening a Roth IRA is step one. Choosing your investment selection -- what you actually buy inside the account -- is step two. This is where many beginners stall out. They open the account, deposit money, and then leave it sitting as cash because they are not sure what to buy. Cash in a Roth IRA earns almost nothing. You need to invest it.

Here are your two best options, from simplest to slightly more involved.

docs.title: Option 1: Target Date Funds (Simplest)
docs.text:
A target-date fund is a single mutual fund that holds a mix of stocks and bonds and automatically adjusts over time. You pick the fund closest to the year you plan to retire, and the fund does everything else.

If you are 25 years old and plan to retire around age 65, that is about 2065. You would pick a 2065 target-date fund. When you are young, the fund holds mostly stocks (for growth). As you get closer to 2065, it gradually shifts toward bonds (for stability). This automatic adjustment is called a "glide path."

Brokerage Target-Date Fund Example Expense Ratio Fidelity Fidelity Freedom Index 2065 (FFIJX) 0.12% Vanguard Vanguard Target Retirement 2065 (VLXVX) 0.08%

The expense ratio is the annual fee the fund charges, expressed as a percentage. An expense ratio of 0.08% means you pay 80 cents per year for every $1,000 invested. That is almost nothing.

Target-date funds are the "set it and forget it" option. If you want to invest without thinking about it, pick one and contribute automatically every month. You are done.

docs.title: Option 2: Three-Fund Portfolio (Slightly More Control)
docs.text:
A three-fund portfolio is a simple investment strategy that uses just three index funds to cover the entire global stock and bond market. It gives you slightly more control over your mix than a target-date fund, with only a tiny bit more effort.

The three funds are:

Fund Type What It Covers Fidelity Option Vanguard Option Suggested Allocation (Age 20s) US Total Stock Market Every publicly traded US company FSKAX (or FZROX, zero fee) VTSAX (or VTI ETF) 60% International Stock Market Companies outside the US FTIHX (or FZILX, zero fee) VTIAX (or VXUS ETF) 30% US Bond Market US government and corporate bonds FXNAX VBTLX (or BND ETF) 10%

At your age, you want mostly stocks because you have decades for your investments to grow and recover from downturns. A split of 60% US stocks, 30% international stocks, and 10% bonds is a reasonable starting point. As you get older and closer to retirement, you gradually increase your bond percentage for stability.

The advantage of the three-fund portfolio over a target-date fund is lower costs (especially with Fidelity's zero-fee funds) and the ability to customize your allocation. The downside is that you need to rebalance once or twice a year -- check if your percentages have drifted and buy or sell to get back to your targets.

Cannot Decide? Start With the Target-Date Fund

If the three-fund portfolio feels overwhelming, go with the target-date fund. You can always switch later once you are more comfortable. The most important thing is to get your money invested, not to pick the perfect portfolio.

docs.title: Roth Conversion: Turning Traditional Money Into Roth Money
docs.text:
A Roth conversion is when you move money from a Traditional IRA (or a Traditional 401(k)) into a Roth IRA. You pay income taxes on the converted amount in the year you do it, but after that, the money grows tax-free in your Roth forever.

Why would someone do this? A few common scenarios:

  • You have an old Traditional IRA or a 401(k) from a previous employer and want to move it into a Roth for tax-free growth going forward.
  • You are in a year with unusually low income (maybe you went back to school or took time off), so your tax rate is temporarily low. Converting during a low-income year means paying less tax on the conversion.
  • You want to avoid required minimum distributions later in life (Traditional accounts force you to start withdrawing at age 73; Roth accounts never do).

The catch: you owe income taxes on the full converted amount in the year you convert. If you convert $20,000 from a Traditional IRA to a Roth IRA, that $20,000 is added to your taxable income for the year. Make sure you have money outside the IRA to pay the tax bill. Do not pay the taxes from the converted amount itself -- that defeats the purpose.

For most young adults just starting out, a Roth conversion is not immediately relevant. You should be contributing directly to a Roth IRA. But it is a powerful tool to know about for the future, especially if your income eventually exceeds the Roth IRA income limits and you need to use the "backdoor Roth" strategy (contributing to a Traditional IRA and then immediately converting to Roth).

docs.title: Required Distributions: Why Roth IRAs Win Again
docs.text:
Required minimum distributions (RMDs) are mandatory withdrawals the IRS forces you to take from certain retirement accounts starting at age 73. Traditional IRAs and Traditional 401(k)s have RMDs. The government gave you a tax break when you put the money in, and they want their taxes eventually.

Here is the problem with RMDs: you might not need or want the money at 73. Maybe your expenses are low in retirement. Maybe you want to leave the money to your kids. Too bad -- the IRS says you have to pull it out and pay taxes on it, whether you need it or not. And if you do not take your RMD, the penalty is steep: 25% of the amount you should have withdrawn.

Roth IRAs have no RMDs. You never have to withdraw if you do not want to. Your money can keep growing tax-free for your entire life and even be passed to your heirs tax-free. This is another major reason the Roth IRA is so valuable for young investors with decades of potential growth ahead.

docs.title: Where Your Money Should Go: The Priority Framework
docs.text:
Now that you understand how the Roth IRA fits into the bigger picture, here is your order of operations. Follow these in sequence:

  1. Build $1,000 starter emergency fund -- Your financial foundation. Nothing else happens until this is done.
  2. Get your full employer 401(k) match -- Free money from your employer. We cover this in Chapter 11.
  3. Pay off high-interest debt (over 7%) -- Credit cards, payday loans, personal loans. Covered in Chapter 6.
  4. Build emergency fund to 3-6 months of expenses -- Full financial safety net. Covered in Chapter 5.
  5. Max out Roth IRA ($7,000/year in 2025) -- This is what this chapter is about. Open one TODAY if you have reached this step.
  6. Invest in low-cost index funds -- Beyond your Roth IRA, use a taxable brokerage account. Covered in Chapters 8-9.
  7. Pay off medium-interest debt (4-7%) -- Car loans, some student loans.
  8. Save for specific goals -- House down payment, wedding, travel.

If you are at Priority #5 and have the ability to contribute, every month you delay opening your Roth IRA is money left on the table. The age 22 vs 32 comparison above proves it: time is the most valuable thing you have. Do not waste it.

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
Mistake #1: "I'll open a Roth IRA when I make more money." This is the most expensive mistake on this list. Every year you delay costs you real money. Even $50 per month is better than $0 per month. A 22-year-old putting in $50/month earns more by age 65 than a 32-year-old putting in $100/month. Start now with whatever you can.

Mistake #2: Opening the account but not investing the money. Depositing money into a Roth IRA does not automatically invest it. If you skip the investment selection step, your money sits as cash earning nearly nothing. After you deposit money, you must buy an investment (a target-date fund or index funds). Check your account -- if it says "cash" or "core position," your money is not invested.

Mistake #3: Trying to pick individual stocks. Your Roth IRA is not a place to gamble on the next big stock. It is a long-term retirement account. Put it in broadly diversified index funds and let compound growth do the work. Stock-picking is fun in theory but loses to index funds the vast majority of the time.

Mistake #4: Withdrawing early. You can withdraw your contributions (the money you put in) at any time without penalty. But withdrawing the growth before age 59.5 triggers taxes and a 10% penalty. Treat your Roth IRA as untouchable until retirement. That said, knowing you can access your contributions in a true emergency provides peace of mind.

Mistake #5: Not knowing about income limits. In 2025, you cannot contribute to a Roth IRA if your modified adjusted gross income is above $150,000 (single) or $236,000 (married filing jointly). If you are approaching these limits, look into the "backdoor Roth" strategy. For most young adults starting out, this is not an issue yet.

Mistake #6: Paying high fees. Some brokerages and financial advisors charge high fees that eat into your returns. Stick with Fidelity or Vanguard. Use index funds with expense ratios below 0.20%. Never pay a "load" (an upfront sales commission) on a mutual fund.

docs.title: Quick Quiz
docs.text:
Test your understanding of Roth IRAs and retirement accounts.

1. What is the main difference between a Roth IRA and a Traditional IRA?

Roth IRA: pay taxes now, withdraw tax-free later. Traditional IRA: get a tax break now, pay taxes when you withdraw. For most young adults, the Roth is better because you are likely in a lower tax bracket now than you will be in retirement.

2. What is the Roth IRA contribution limit for 2025 (under age 50)?

$7,000 per year. This is the combined limit across all your IRAs. You can contribute up to $7,000 total between Roth and Traditional IRAs, not $7,000 to each.

3. Alex starts investing $7,000/year at age 22. Jordan starts at age 32. Both earn 10% average returns and retire at 65. Approximately how much more does Alex have?

About $2 million more. Alex ends up with roughly $3.2 million while Jordan ends up with roughly $1.2 million. Alex contributed only $70,000 more but ends up with $2 million more because of compound growth over the extra ten years.

4. You deposit $7,000 into your Roth IRA but do not select any investments. What happens?

Your money sits as cash, earning almost nothing. Depositing money into a Roth IRA does not automatically invest it. You must choose an investment (like a target-date fund or index funds) after making your deposit.

5. What is a target-date fund?

A single fund that holds a mix of stocks and bonds and automatically adjusts over time based on your expected retirement year. If you plan to retire around 2065, you pick a 2065 target-date fund. It starts stock-heavy for growth and gradually shifts to bonds for stability as you approach retirement.

6. What are required minimum distributions (RMDs), and do they apply to Roth IRAs?

RMDs are mandatory withdrawals the IRS requires from Traditional retirement accounts starting at age 73. Roth IRAs do NOT have RMDs. You never have to withdraw from a Roth IRA if you do not want to, which means your money can keep growing tax-free indefinitely.

docs.title: Key Terms
docs.text:
• Roth IRA: A retirement investment account where you contribute after-tax money, your investments grow tax-free, and qualified withdrawals in retirement are completely tax-free. Named after Senator William Roth, who helped create it in 1997.

  • Traditional IRA: A retirement account where contributions may be tax-deductible (reducing your taxes today), but withdrawals in retirement are taxed as ordinary income. Growth is tax-deferred, not tax-free.

  • IRA Contribution Limits: The maximum amount the IRS allows you to contribute to your IRAs each year. For 2025, the limit is $7,000 per year (under age 50) or $8,000 (age 50 and older). This is a combined limit across all your IRAs.

  • Tax-Free Growth: Investment growth that is never taxed -- not when it happens, not when you withdraw it. This is the key benefit of a Roth IRA. Your contributions and all their growth come out tax-free in retirement.

  • Tax-Deferred Growth: Investment growth that is not taxed now but will be taxed when you withdraw it in retirement. Traditional IRAs and 401(k)s use this model. "Deferred" means postponed, not eliminated.

  • Required Distributions (RMDs): Mandatory minimum withdrawals the IRS requires you to take from Traditional IRAs and 401(k)s starting at age 73. Failure to take your RMD results in a 25% penalty on the amount you should have withdrawn. Roth IRAs have no RMDs.

  • Roth Conversion: The process of moving money from a Traditional IRA or 401(k) into a Roth IRA. You pay income taxes on the converted amount in the year of conversion, but the money then grows tax-free in the Roth going forward.

  • Investment Selection: The specific funds or securities you choose to buy inside your IRA. Simply depositing money is not enough -- you must actively invest it in stocks, bonds, or funds for it to grow.

  • Target Date Fund: A single mutual fund that holds a diversified mix of stocks and bonds and automatically adjusts its allocation over time based on a target retirement year. It becomes more conservative (more bonds, fewer stocks) as the target date approaches.

  • Three-Fund Portfolio: An investment strategy using just three index funds (US total stock market, international stock market, and US bond market) to achieve broad diversification at very low cost. A popular approach for DIY investors who want simplicity with some control.

  • Fidelity: One of the largest investment brokerages in the US. Known for no-minimum accounts, zero-expense-ratio index funds, fractional shares, and a user-friendly platform. An excellent choice for opening a Roth IRA.

  • Vanguard: The investment company that pioneered low-cost index fund investing. Uniquely structured so that it is owned by its fund shareholders. Known for very low expense ratios and a long-term investing philosophy. Another excellent choice for opening a Roth IRA.

docs.title: What To Do This Week
docs.text:
Here is your action plan. If you have completed Priorities #1 through #4, do these steps this week. If not, bookmark this page and come back when you are ready.

  • Day 1: Decide between Fidelity and Vanguard. Read the step-by-step instructions above for each one. Pick whichever appeals to you more. Either is a great choice -- do not let this decision take more than 10 minutes.
  • Day 2: Open your Roth IRA. Follow the step-by-step guide above. Gather your Social Security number, bank account info, and ID. The process takes about 15 minutes.
  • Day 3: Make your first contribution. Even if it is $100. Transfer money from your checking account into your new Roth IRA. Remember, you can contribute up to $7,000 for the 2025 tax year.
  • Day 4: Invest your contribution. Do not leave it as cash. Pick a target-date fund matching your expected retirement year (2060 or 2065 for most readers). Buy it. You are now invested.
  • Day 5: Set up automatic monthly contributions. Even \(100/month (\)1,200/year) puts you ahead of most Americans. Pick a date right after payday and automate the transfer and investment.
  • Weekend: Run the numbers yourself. Use the Roth IRA Growth Calculator MicroSim above. Enter your age, your planned monthly contribution, and see what your account could look like at 65. Then try adding 10 years to your starting age and see what you lose. Let those numbers motivate you.

Every month you wait to open your Roth IRA costs you money you will never get back. The best time to start was yesterday. The second best time is right now.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: This chapter explains how to capture free money through your employer's 401(k) match. If your employer matches 3% and you earn $40,000, that's $1,200 FREE per year you're leaving on the table if you don't contribute. You'll learn about Traditional vs Roth 401(k), the $23,500 contribution limit for 2025, vesting schedules, what happens when you change jobs, and the incredible triple tax advantage of HSA accounts.

docs.title: Concepts Covered
docs.text:
This chapter covers the following 9 concepts from the learning graph:

  1. 401(k)
  2. Employer Match
  3. Vesting Schedule
  4. Roth 401(k)
  5. 401(k) Rollover
  6. HSA Account
  7. Triple Tax Advantage
  8. Employee Benefits
  9. Open Enrollment

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
This chapter builds on concepts from:

  • Chapter 7: Taxes & Tax Optimization
  • Chapter 8: Introduction to Investing
  • Chapter 10: Roth IRA & Retirement Accounts
  • Chapter 16: Insurance & Risk Protection (Health Insurance concepts)

docs.title: Introduction: Don't Leave Free Money on the Table
docs.text:
Imagine your boss walks up to you and says, "Hey, for every dollar you set aside for retirement, I'll hand you a dollar too. Up to a certain amount." You would take that deal instantly, right? That is exactly what an employer 401(k) match is. It is free money added to your retirement account just for participating.

Yet roughly one in five eligible workers does not contribute enough to get their full employer match. That means millions of people are literally saying "no thanks" to free money every single paycheck.

Getting your full employer match is Priority #2 in your financial plan, right after building your $1,000 starter emergency fund. It comes before paying off high-interest debt. It comes before maxing out a Roth IRA. Why? Because no debt payoff strategy and no investment can guarantee you an instant 50% to 100% return on your money. An employer match does exactly that.

This chapter will walk you through everything you need to know about 401(k) plans, employer benefits, and one of the best-kept secrets in personal finance: the HSA triple tax advantage. By the end, you will know exactly how to capture every dollar your employer is willing to give you.

docs.title: What Is a 401(k)?
docs.text:
A 401(k) is a retirement savings account offered through your employer. The name comes from Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code -- not exactly exciting, but the benefits are. Here is what makes a 401(k) special compared to a regular savings account:

  • Tax advantages -- your contributions either reduce your taxable income now (Traditional) or grow tax-free (Roth). We will break down the difference shortly.
  • Employer matching -- many employers will add their own money to your account when you contribute. This is the free money we keep talking about.
  • Automatic payroll deductions -- money comes out of your paycheck before you ever see it, making saving effortless.
  • High contribution limits -- you can contribute up to $23,500 per year in 2025, which is far more than the $7,000 Roth IRA limit you learned about in Chapter 10.

docs.title: How It Works in Practice
docs.text:
When you start a new job that offers a 401(k), you choose a percentage of your paycheck to contribute. That money is automatically deducted each pay period and invested in the funds you select within the plan. You pick from a menu of investment options, typically a mix of stock funds, bond funds, and target-date funds.

Here is a simple example. Say you earn $40,000 a year and decide to contribute 6% of your pay:

  • \( \$40{,}000 \times 0.06 = \$2{,}400 \) per year
  • That is \( \$2{,}400 \div 24 = \$100 \) per paycheck (if paid twice a month)

That $100 per paycheck goes straight into your 401(k) before you can spend it. Over time, it gets invested and grows through compound interest, the same force you learned about in Chapter 8.

docs.title: Employer Match: The Best Deal in Personal Finance
docs.text:
An employer match is when your company contributes additional money to your 401(k) based on how much you put in. Think of it as a bonus that shows up every paycheck, but only if you participate.

Common match formulas include:

  • Dollar-for-dollar up to a percentage -- your employer matches 100% of your contribution, up to a cap. Example: 100% match on the first 3% of your salary.
  • Fifty cents on the dollar -- your employer puts in $0.50 for every $1.00 you contribute, up to a cap. Example: 50% match on the first 6% of your salary.
  • Tiered matching -- different match rates at different levels. Example: 100% on the first 3%, then 50% on the next 2%.

The most common formula in the United States is a 50% match on the first 6% of your salary. That effectively means if you contribute 6%, your employer adds another 3%. Let that sink in: 3% of your salary, handed to you for free.

docs.title: Employer Match at Three Salary Levels
docs.text:
Here is what the numbers look like at different salaries, using the most common match formula (50% match on first 6%):

Salary: $40,000 Salary: $60,000 Salary: $80,000 Your contribution (6%) $2,400/year $3,600/year $4,800/year Employer match (3%) $1,200/year $1,800/year $2,400/year Total going into your 401(k) $3,600/year $5,400/year $7,200/year Free money over 10 years $12,000+ $18,000+ $24,000+ Free money over 30 years $36,000+ $54,000+ $72,000+

This Is Not Optional

If you earn $40,000 and your employer offers a 50% match on the first 6%, not contributing at least 6% means you are throwing away $1,200 every single year. Over a 30-year career, that is $36,000 in free money you never received -- and that is before investment growth. With average market returns, that lost match could grow to over $100,000. There is no financial strategy that can make up for turning down free money.

docs.title: What If Your Employer Matches Dollar-for-Dollar?
docs.text:
Some employers are even more generous. If your company offers a 100% match on the first 3%, here is how the numbers change:

Salary: $40,000 Salary: $60,000 Salary: $80,000 Your contribution (3%) $1,200/year $1,800/year $2,400/year Employer match (3%) $1,200/year $1,800/year $2,400/year Total going into your 401(k) $2,400/year $3,600/year $4,800/year

With a dollar-for-dollar match, your money doubles instantly. That is a 100% return on your investment on day one. No stock, no crypto, no side hustle can guarantee that.

docs.title: But What Do I Actually DO With This?
docs.text:
1. Find out your employer's match formula. Check your benefits portal, ask HR, or look at the benefits packet you received when you were hired.
  2. At minimum, contribute enough to get the full match. If the match is 50% on 6%, contribute at least 6%. If it is 100% on 3%, contribute at least 3%.
  3. Set this up on your first day if possible. Many companies auto-enroll new employees at 3%, which might not be enough to capture the full match. Double-check and increase if needed.

docs.title: MicroSim: 401(k) Match Calculator
docs.text: Use this calculator to enter your salary and your employer's match formula. See exactly how much free money you are capturing -- or leaving on the table.

docs.title: Traditional vs Roth 401(k)
docs.text:
Most employers now offer two flavors of 401(k): Traditional and Roth. The core difference is simple: do you want to pay taxes now, or pay taxes later?

A Traditional 401(k) uses pre-tax dollars. Your contributions reduce your taxable income today, so you pay less in taxes right now. But when you withdraw the money in retirement, you pay income tax on everything -- your contributions and all the growth.

A Roth 401(k) uses after-tax dollars. You pay taxes on the money before it goes in, so your paycheck feels a bit smaller today. But when you withdraw the money in retirement, it is completely tax-free -- contributions and all the growth.

Here is a side-by-side comparison:

Feature Traditional 401(k) Roth 401(k) Tax on contributions No tax now (pre-tax) Taxed now (after-tax) Tax on withdrawals Taxed as income Tax-free Tax on investment growth Taxed when withdrawn Tax-free Effect on today's paycheck Larger (lower taxes now) Smaller (taxes paid now) Best if you expect... Lower tax rate in retirement Higher tax rate in retirement 2025 contribution limit $23,500 $23,500 Required minimum distributions Yes, at age 73 Yes, at age 73 (but can roll to Roth IRA to avoid) Employer match goes into... Traditional (pre-tax) account Traditional (pre-tax) account*

*Even if you choose Roth 401(k) contributions, your employer's matching dollars always go into a Traditional (pre-tax) account. This is a tax rule, not an employer choice.

docs.title: Which One Should You Pick?
docs.text:
For most young adults, the Roth 401(k) is likely the better choice. Here is why:

  • You are probably in a lower tax bracket now than you will be later in your career. Paying taxes at today's low rate and then withdrawing tax-free in retirement is a great deal.
  • Tax-free growth over 30 to 40 years is enormously powerful. The bigger your account grows, the more valuable that tax-free status becomes.
  • Nobody knows what tax rates will look like in 30 years. Locking in tax-free withdrawals now eliminates that uncertainty.

However, the Traditional 401(k) might make sense if you are in a high tax bracket today and expect to be in a much lower bracket in retirement, or if you need the immediate tax deduction to manage your current budget.

Not Sure? Split It

Some employers let you split contributions between Traditional and Roth. You could put 50% in each. This gives you tax diversification in retirement -- some taxable money and some tax-free money -- which gives you flexibility no matter what happens with tax rates.

docs.title: A Quick Math Example
docs.text:
Say you contribute $200 per paycheck to your 401(k) and you are in the 22% federal tax bracket:

  • Traditional 401(k): The full $200 goes in. Your paycheck only drops by about $156 (because you save $44 in taxes). But you will owe taxes on every dollar when you withdraw.
  • Roth 401(k): The full $200 goes in, but your paycheck drops by the full $200 (taxes already paid). When you withdraw in retirement, every dollar is tax-free.

The contribution limit of $23,500 for 2025 applies to the total of your Traditional and Roth 401(k) contributions combined. You cannot put $23,500 in each.

docs.title: Vesting Schedules: When the Free Money Is Actually Yours
docs.text:
Here is something that trips up a lot of people. Just because your employer puts matching money into your 401(k) does not mean you get to keep it immediately. Many companies use a vesting schedule that determines how much of the employer match you actually own based on how long you have worked there.

A vesting schedule is a timeline that dictates when employer contributions become fully yours. Your own contributions are always 100% yours from day one. It is only the employer's matching dollars that might have a vesting schedule attached.

There are two common types:

Cliff vesting -- you own 0% of the match until a specific date (usually 3 years), then you own 100% all at once.

Graded vesting -- you gradually earn ownership over several years.

Here is what a typical graded vesting schedule looks like:

Years of Service Percentage Vested What You Keep (on $1,200 match) Less than 1 year 0% $0 1 year 20% $240 2 years 40% $480 3 years 60% $720 4 years 80% $960 5 years 100% $1,200

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
If you leave a job after 2 years with a graded vesting schedule, you only keep 40% of the employer match. On a $1,200 annual match, that means $720 stays in your account and $480 goes back to the employer.

This does NOT mean you should avoid contributing. The match is still free money -- even keeping 40% of it is better than keeping 0%. But it is something to factor into your decision if you are thinking about leaving a job. If you are at 80% vested and your 5-year mark is three months away, it might be worth sticking around to capture that last 20%.

docs.title: But What Do I Actually DO With This?
docs.text:
1. Ask HR about your vesting schedule when you start a new job.
  2. Check your 401(k) statement. It should show your "vested balance" separately from your total balance.
  3. Factor vesting into job-change decisions. If you are close to a vesting milestone, do the math before you leave.

docs.title: What Happens When You Change Jobs: The 401(k) Rollover
docs.text:
The average person changes jobs about 12 times during their career. That means you will eventually face this question: what do I do with my old 401(k)?

A 401(k) rollover is the process of moving money from an old employer's 401(k) into another retirement account. You have four options:

Option What Happens Recommended? Roll over to an IRA Move the money to a Traditional or Roth IRA at a brokerage like Fidelity or Vanguard Best option for most people Roll over to new employer's 401(k) Transfer to your new job's plan Good if the new plan has great funds Leave it in old employer's plan Money stays where it is Fine short-term, but you may forget about it Cash it out Take the money as cash Almost always a terrible idea

docs.title: Why Rolling Over to an IRA Is Usually Best
docs.text:
When you roll your old 401(k) into an IRA, you get several advantages:

  • More investment choices. Most 401(k) plans offer 20-30 fund options. An IRA at Fidelity or Vanguard gives you access to thousands, often with lower fees.
  • Lower fees. Many 401(k) plans charge administrative fees. IRAs at major brokerages often have no account fees.
  • Simplicity. Instead of having old 401(k) accounts scattered across former employers, you have everything in one place.

docs.title: Why You Should Never Cash Out
docs.text:
If you cash out your 401(k) before age 59 and a half, you will owe income taxes on the entire amount plus a 10% early withdrawal penalty. On a $10,000 balance in the 22% tax bracket:

  • Federal income tax: \( \$10{,}000 \times 0.22 = \$2{,}200 \)
  • Early withdrawal penalty: \( \$10{,}000 \times 0.10 = \$1{,}000 \)
  • You keep only $6,800 out of $10,000

And you lose all the future growth that money would have generated. That $10,000 invested for 30 years at 7% average returns would have grown to about $76,000. Cashing out costs you far more than you realize.

docs.title: How to Do a Rollover: Step by Step
docs.text:
1. Open an IRA at your preferred brokerage (Fidelity, Vanguard, or Schwab are all excellent choices).
  2. Contact your old 401(k) provider and request a "direct rollover" to your new IRA. Emphasize "direct rollover" -- this means the money goes straight from your old account to your new account without you touching it, which avoids any tax issues.
  3. Choose your investments in the new IRA. A target-date fund or a simple three-fund portfolio (as covered in Chapter 10) are solid starting points.
  4. Confirm the transfer. It usually takes 1-3 weeks. Check both accounts to make sure the money arrived.

Rolling Over a Traditional 401(k) to a Roth IRA

You can roll a Traditional 401(k) into a Roth IRA, but you will owe income taxes on the converted amount since the money was never taxed. This is called a Roth conversion. It can be a smart move if you are in a low tax bracket and want tax-free growth going forward, but make sure you have cash on hand to pay the tax bill. Do not use the retirement funds themselves to pay the taxes.

docs.title: HSA: The Secret Weapon of Employee Benefits
docs.text:
If your employer offers a high-deductible health plan (HDHP), you likely have access to a Health Savings Account (HSA). Most people think of an HSA as just a medical spending account. It is actually one of the most powerful tax-advantaged accounts in existence.

An HSA is a tax-advantaged savings account designed to help you pay for qualified medical expenses. To be eligible, you must be enrolled in a high-deductible health plan (in 2025, that means a plan with a deductible of at least $1,650 for individuals or $3,300 for families).

docs.title: The Triple Tax Advantage
docs.text:
Here is what makes the HSA extraordinary. It is the only account in the U.S. tax code that offers a triple tax advantage:

  1. Tax-free contributions -- money goes in before taxes, reducing your taxable income (just like a Traditional 401(k)).
  2. Tax-free growth -- your investments grow without being taxed (just like a Roth IRA).
  3. Tax-free withdrawals -- when you spend the money on qualified medical expenses, you pay zero tax on the way out.

No other account gives you all three. A Traditional 401(k) gives you #1 and #2 but taxes you on withdrawals. A Roth IRA gives you #2 and #3 but taxes you on contributions. The HSA gives you all three.

docs.title: Diagram: HSA Triple Tax Advantage
docs.text:
HSA Triple Tax Advantage - How It Compares 
                    Tax-Free     Tax-Free     Tax-Free
                  Contributions   Growth     Withdrawals
                  ───────────   ─────────   ───────────
Traditional 401(k)     YES          YES          NO
                       ✓            ✓            ✗

Roth IRA               NO          YES          YES
                       ✗            ✓            ✓

HSA                    YES          YES          YES
                       ✓            ✓            ✓
                  ═══════════   ═════════   ═══════════
                  ONLY the HSA gets all three tax benefits!

How it works:

  Your Paycheck ──→ HSA (no tax) ──→ Invested & Growing (no tax)
                                          │
                                          ▼
                                   Medical Expense?
                                    ╱           ╲
                                  YES            NO
                                  ╱               ╲
                            Withdraw           Keep Investing
                          (no tax!)          (still no tax on growth)
                                               │
                                               ▼
                                          After age 65:
                                     Withdraw for ANY reason
                                    (taxed like regular income,
                                     but no penalty)

docs.title: HSA Contribution Limits for 2025
docs.text: Individual Family Annual contribution limit $4,300 $8,550 Catch-up contribution (age 55+) +$1,000 +$1,000

docs.title: The Secret HSA Strategy: Invest and Wait
docs.text:
Here is where the HSA gets really interesting. You do not have to spend your HSA money right away. You can pay for medical expenses out of pocket, let your HSA investments grow for decades, and then reimburse yourself later. There is no time limit on reimbursement.

The strategy:

  1. Contribute the maximum to your HSA each year.
  2. Invest the balance in low-cost index funds (many HSA providers offer investment options once your balance reaches a certain threshold, often \(1,000-\)2,000).
  3. Pay current medical bills out of pocket if you can afford to. Save your receipts.
  4. Let the HSA grow for years or decades.
  5. Reimburse yourself tax-free whenever you want, using those saved receipts.

If you contribute \(4,300 per year for 30 years and earn an average 7% return, your HSA could grow to over **\)400,000** -- all tax-free for medical expenses. And after age 65, you can withdraw for any purpose (not just medical) and pay only regular income tax, similar to a Traditional IRA. No penalty.

Keep Your Receipts

If you use the invest-and-wait strategy, save every medical receipt in a folder (digital is fine). You can reimburse yourself for a doctor visit you paid for in 2025 using HSA funds in 2045. The receipt is your proof that it was a qualified expense.

docs.title: Employee Benefits: More Than Just the 401(k)
docs.text:
Your employee benefits package is a significant part of your total compensation. Many young adults focus only on salary and ignore benefits worth thousands of dollars per year. Here are the most common benefits to look for and understand:

  • Health insurance -- employer-sponsored plans are usually much cheaper than buying insurance on your own. The employer typically pays 70-80% of the premium.
  • Dental and vision insurance -- often inexpensive through an employer (sometimes under $20/month).
  • Life insurance -- many employers provide free basic coverage equal to one or two times your annual salary.
  • Disability insurance -- protects your income if you get injured or sick and cannot work. Short-term and long-term options.
  • 401(k) with match -- the free money we have been discussing.
  • HSA or FSA -- tax-advantaged health spending accounts.
  • Employee stock purchase plan (ESPP) -- some companies let you buy company stock at a discount, often 10-15% below market price.
  • Education benefits -- tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment assistance, or professional development funds.
  • Paid time off (PTO) -- vacation days, sick days, and personal days.

When evaluating a job offer, do not just compare salaries. A job paying $50,000 with a 100% match on 5% and free health insurance could be worth more than a $55,000 job with no match and expensive insurance.

docs.title: Open Enrollment: Your Annual Benefits Window
docs.text: Open enrollment is the period each year (usually in the fall, around October-November) when you can sign up for, change, or cancel your employer benefits for the upcoming year. Outside of this window, you typically cannot make changes unless you have a "qualifying life event" like getting married, having a baby, or losing other coverage.

docs.title: Your Open Enrollment Checklist
docs.text:
Open enrollment can feel overwhelming when you get a stack of paperwork or a confusing benefits portal. Use this checklist to make sure you are covering the essentials:

  • Review your 401(k) contribution. Are you contributing at least enough to get the full employer match? Can you afford to increase it by 1%?
  • Choose Traditional or Roth 401(k). Revisit this decision each year as your income changes.
  • Select your health insurance plan. Compare premiums (monthly cost), deductibles (what you pay before insurance kicks in), and out-of-pocket maximums. If you are young and healthy, a high-deductible plan with an HSA can save you money.
  • Maximize your HSA. If you have a high-deductible plan, set your HSA contribution to the max ($4,300 individual / $8,550 family for 2025).
  • Enroll in dental and vision if the cost is reasonable.
  • Check life and disability insurance. The free basic coverage is usually enough for young adults without dependents, but review it.
  • Look into ESPP. If your company offers an employee stock purchase plan with a discount, it can be a good deal. Just do not put all your eggs in one basket -- diversify.
  • Use education benefits. If your employer offers tuition reimbursement or professional development funds, use them. Free education is free education.
  • Update your beneficiaries. This is the person who receives your retirement accounts and life insurance if something happens to you. Keep it current.
  • Save your benefits summary. Keep a copy of your elections so you can reference them during the year.

Don't Just Click Through

The biggest open enrollment mistake is keeping last year's elections without reviewing them. Plans change. Prices change. Your life changes. Take 30 minutes each year to review everything. Those 30 minutes could save you hundreds or thousands of dollars.

docs.title: Where Your Money Should Go: The Priority Framework
docs.text:
Now that you understand all the pieces, here is how 401(k) and employer benefits fit into the overall priority framework:

Priority Action Why It Comes in This Order #1 Build $1,000 starter emergency fund Basic safety net against common emergencies #2 Get full employer 401(k) match Free money. Instant 50-100% return. Nothing else competes. #3 Pay off high-interest debt (over 7%) High-interest debt erodes wealth faster than investments grow #4 Build emergency fund to 3-6 months Full financial safety net #5 Max out Roth IRA ($7,000/year) Tax-free growth in an account you fully control #6 Invest in low-cost index funds Build long-term wealth beyond retirement accounts #7 Pay off medium-interest debt (4-7%) Clean up remaining debt #8 Save for specific goals House down payment, travel, education

Notice that the full employer match comes at Priority #2 -- before paying off credit card debt, before a Roth IRA, before everything else except your starter emergency fund. This is because no investment reliably delivers an instant 50-100% guaranteed return. The employer match does. If you have high-interest debt, contribute just enough to get the full match, then throw everything else at the debt.

Where does the HSA fit? If you have access to one, max it out alongside your 401(k) match at Priority #2 because of the triple tax advantage. If you cannot afford to do both, get the full 401(k) match first.

docs.title: Common Mistakes (and How to Avoid Them)
docs.text:
Mistake #1: Not contributing enough to get the full match. This is by far the most expensive mistake on this list. If your employer matches 50% on 6% and you only contribute 3%, you are leaving half the free money on the table. Always contribute at least enough to capture the full match.

Mistake #2: Cashing out your 401(k) when you leave a job. You lose 30%+ to taxes and penalties, plus decades of growth. Roll it over to an IRA instead. It takes about 30 minutes and saves you tens of thousands of dollars.

Mistake #3: Keeping the default investment in a money market fund. Some 401(k) plans default your contributions to a low-yield money market or stable value fund. Check your investments and make sure you are in a diversified portfolio. A target-date fund is an easy, solid choice if you are not sure.

Mistake #4: Ignoring the HSA investment option. Most people treat their HSA like a checking account for doctor visits. If you can afford to pay medical expenses out of pocket, invest your HSA balance in index funds and let it grow tax-free for decades.

Mistake #5: Not increasing contributions over time. Every time you get a raise, increase your 401(k) contribution by at least 1%. You will not miss money you never saw in your paycheck, and your future self will thank you.

Mistake #6: Skipping open enrollment. Benefits are not "set it and forget it." Review and optimize your elections every year during open enrollment. Plans change, premiums change, and your needs change.

docs.title: Quick Quiz
docs.text:
Test your understanding of the key concepts from this chapter.

1. If your employer matches 50% of your contributions up to 6% of your salary, and you earn $60,000, how much free money do you get per year if you contribute 6%?

Answer

$1,800 per year. You contribute 6% of $60,000 = $3,600. Your employer matches 50% of that = $1,800. That is $1,800 of free money per year.

2. What is the 2025 401(k) employee contribution limit?

Answer

$23,500 per year. This is the combined limit for Traditional and Roth 401(k) contributions.

3. What are the three tax advantages of an HSA?

Answer

Tax-free contributions (money goes in pre-tax), tax-free growth (investments are not taxed), and tax-free withdrawals (for qualified medical expenses). No other account gets all three.

4. You have been at your company for 3 years. Your employer uses a graded vesting schedule (20% per year). You have $5,000 in employer match contributions. How much can you keep if you leave?

Answer

$3,000. At 3 years, you are 60% vested. \( \$5{,}000 \times 0.60 = \$3{,}000 \). The remaining $2,000 goes back to the employer.

5. Why is getting the full employer match Priority #2 in the financial plan, ahead of paying off high-interest debt?

Answer

Because the employer match is a guaranteed, instant 50-100% return on your money. No debt payoff strategy or investment can reliably match that return. You should contribute enough to get the full match, then direct extra money toward high-interest debt.

docs.title: Key Terms
docs.text: Term Definition 401(k) A retirement savings account offered through your employer with tax advantages and often employer matching contributions. Contribution limit is $23,500 for 2025. Employer Match Free money your employer adds to your 401(k) based on how much you contribute. Common formula: 50% match on the first 6% of salary. Vesting Schedule A timeline that determines when employer matching contributions become fully yours. Your own contributions are always 100% yours. Roth 401(k) A 401(k) option where you pay taxes on contributions now but withdrawals in retirement are completely tax-free. Best for most young adults. Traditional 401(k) A 401(k) option where contributions reduce your taxes now but withdrawals in retirement are taxed as income. 401(k) Rollover Moving money from an old employer's 401(k) to an IRA or new employer's plan when you change jobs. Always do a direct rollover. HSA (Health Savings Account) A tax-advantaged account for medical expenses, available with high-deductible health plans. Offers the triple tax advantage. Triple Tax Advantage The unique HSA benefit: tax-free contributions, tax-free growth, and tax-free withdrawals for medical expenses. No other account has all three. Employee Benefits The full package of non-salary compensation from your employer, including insurance, retirement plans, PTO, and more. Open Enrollment The annual window (usually fall) to sign up for, change, or cancel your employer benefits for the next year.

docs.title: What To Do This Week
docs.text:
You have the knowledge. Now take action. Here are concrete steps to complete this week:

Day 1-2: Find your match. Log into your employer's benefits portal or call HR. Find the exact match formula. Write it down: "My employer matches % of my contribution up to % of my salary."

Day 2-3: Check your contribution. Are you contributing enough to get the full match? If not, log in and increase your contribution today. If you are already getting the full match, see if you can increase by 1%.

Day 3-4: Check your investments. Look at what your 401(k) money is invested in. If it is sitting in a money market or stable value fund, switch to a target-date fund closest to the year you turn 65.

Day 4-5: Check your vesting. Find out your vesting schedule and how much of your employer match you currently own. This is listed on your 401(k) statement or benefits portal.

Day 5-6: Evaluate your HSA. If you have a high-deductible health plan, check whether you have an HSA and whether you are contributing. If you are contributing, check whether the balance is invested or just sitting in cash.

Day 6-7: Gather your benefits summary. Find your most recent benefits elections and save them somewhere accessible. Note the next open enrollment date on your calendar.

You do not need to do everything perfectly right away. The single most important action is to make sure you are contributing enough to get the full employer match. That one change alone could be worth hundreds of thousands of dollars over your career. Do not leave free money on the table.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: This chapter explores ways to build income that doesn't require trading your time for money. You'll learn about dividend investing, rental income, digital products, content creation, and royalties. Most importantly, you'll separate realistic passive income expectations from social media hype and understand that most "passive" income requires significant upfront work.

docs.title: Concepts Covered
docs.text:
This chapter covers the following 8 concepts from the learning graph:

  1. Passive Income
  2. Dividend Investing
  3. Rental Income
  4. Digital Products
  5. Content Creation Income
  6. Royalties
  7. Income Streams
  8. Active vs Passive Income

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
This chapter builds on concepts from:

  • Chapter 8: Introduction to Investing
  • Chapter 9: Stock Market Fundamentals (dividends)

docs.title: Introduction: The Truth About Passive Income
docs.text:
Open any social media app and you will find someone claiming to earn $10,000 a month "while they sleep." They will show you screenshots of their income dashboard, film themselves on a beach with a laptop, and tell you that you are foolish for trading your time for money at a regular job. They make it look effortless.

Here is the honest truth: passive income is real, but it is almost never effortless. Every legitimate passive income stream requires one of two things upfront -- a large amount of money, a large amount of work, or both. That person earning $10,000 per month from an online course spent six months building it and three years building an audience first. The person collecting $2,000 per month in dividends has over $800,000 invested. Nobody tells you that part.

This does not mean passive income is a scam. It means you need to go in with realistic expectations and honest math. This chapter will give you both. By the end, you will understand which passive income streams are realistic for someone in their twenties, how much they actually cost to start, and how to take your first real steps toward building income that works even when you are not.

Where Does Passive Income Fit in Your Priorities?

Passive income is exciting, but it is not where beginners should start. Follow the priority framework first: (1) build your $1,000 starter emergency fund, (2) get your full employer 401(k) match, (3) pay off high-interest debt above 7%, (4) build your emergency fund to 3-6 months, (5) max out your Roth IRA, (6) invest in low-cost index funds. Once you have those foundations in place, passive income projects are a great next step. Do not skip ahead.

docs.title: Active vs. Passive Income: What Is the Difference?
docs.text:
Let us start with the most fundamental question. Active income is money you earn by directly trading your time and effort for pay. If you stop working, the money stops. Your job, hourly wages, freelance gigs, and consulting work are all active income. If you take two weeks off, you earn nothing for those two weeks.

Passive income is money that continues to come in with little or no ongoing effort after the initial work or investment is done. The key phrase is "after the initial work or investment." Nothing starts passively. You either invest money upfront, invest time upfront, or both.

Here is a helpful way to think about it: active income is like pumping water by hand. You pump, water flows. You stop pumping, water stops. Passive income is like building a well. It takes significant effort to dig the well, but once it is built, water flows with minimal maintenance.

Feature Active Income Passive Income How you earn it Trading time for money directly Income flows after upfront work or investment Examples Salary, hourly wages, freelancing, consulting Dividends, rental income, digital product sales, royalties What happens if you stop Income stops immediately Income continues (with some maintenance) Upfront cost Low (just your time) High (money, time, or both) Scaling Limited by hours in the day Can grow without proportional time increase Time to first dollar Immediate (first paycheck) Weeks, months, or years Risk Low (guaranteed pay for work done) Higher (no guarantee of return on investment)

Most financially successful people have both types. Their active income pays the bills today, while their passive income streams build long-term wealth and eventually provide financial freedom. The goal is not to quit your job tomorrow. The goal is to build income streams gradually so that one day, working becomes a choice rather than a requirement.

docs.title: What Is Passive Income, Really?
docs.text:
Passive income is earnings from a source that does not require your active, ongoing involvement to maintain. That is the textbook definition. But in practice, almost no income is truly 100% passive. Even the most hands-off investments require occasional decisions, tax filing, and monitoring.

A more honest definition: passive income is income where the ratio of time invested to money earned improves dramatically over time. In the first year of building a passive income stream, you might earn $5 per hour of effort. By year three, that same stream might be earning you $50 per hour of effort -- or more -- because the hard work is done and the income keeps flowing.

Think of passive income as existing on a spectrum rather than being a binary switch.
